derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English (originally an adjective in the sense 'divorced'): from Latin repudiatus 'divorced, cast off', from repudium 'divorce'

entry.def: If you repudiate something or someone, you show that you strongly disagree with them and do not want to be connected with them in any way.

example.ex: Leaders urged people to turn out in large numbers to repudiate the violence...
example.tran: 领导们力劝人们集体出面反对暴力。

example.ex: The Prime Minister has repudiated racist remarks made by a member of the Conservative Party.
example.tran: 首相已经驳斥了一个保守党成员的种族主义言论。

means.word_mean: 2. refuse to acknowledge, ratify, or recognize as valid;
4. reject as untrue, unfounded, or unjust;

auth_sentence.content: Points three through six do nothing to repudiate ID.

auth_sentence.content: There was no way for him to repudiate the book.

stems_affixes.word_buile: im不+pud感到羞耻+ent……的→不羞耻→无礼的
im不+pud感到羞耻+icity→不感觉羞耻
re反+pud感到羞耻+iate表动词→反过来让别人羞耻→拒绝别人

means.word_mean: 拒绝接受, 否认, 否定

sentences.en: He used his position to repudiate the charge.
sentences.cn: 他利用自己的职位来否认指控。

sentences.en: The West has chosen to repudiate all responsibility for these refugees.
sentences.cn: 西方国家执意拒绝对这些难民承担任何义务。

sentences.en: to repudiate an article/ a report / a claim
sentences.cn: 驳斥一篇文章/ 一份报告/ 一项权利要求

sentences.en: to repudiate a contract/ an agreement

means.word_mean: 拒绝与……往来； 断绝同……的关系

sentences.en: He repudiated his first wife and married her sister.
sentences.cn: 他和第一个妻子离了婚，又娶了她的妹妹。
